headline: U.K.'s Cameron Lays Ground for Cuts
summary: The U.K. government would have to pay $101.33 billion in interest on its debt by 2015 if it doesn't take urgent action to cut borrowing, Prime Minister David Cameron said.

headline: Gates Foundation to Focus on Maternal, Child Health
summary: The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation said it will spend $1.5 billion over the next five years on maternal and child health, family planning and nutrition in developing countries, signaling a new focus for the foundation.

headline: Hands Down
summary: None

headline: Carlyle Invests in Asian Firms
summary: Carlyle said it invested $140 million for minority stakes in four companies in South Korea, India and China.

summary: South Dakota's lone member of the House, Stephanie Herseth Sandlin, is facing an increasingly tough challenge in a race Republicans are depending on in their bid to recapture the House.

headline: Dubai Islamic Bank Faces Legal Fight in Bahrain
summary: Dubai Islamic Bank, the emirate's largest Shariah-compliant lender, faces a $651 million legal battle in Bahrain with four businessmen who it accuses separately of fraud in Dubai.

headline: Israel Kills Diving 'Squad' Off Gaza

headline: Emulex to Buy Private Chip Maker
summary: Emulex has agreed to buy ServerEngines, a privately held semiconductor company, in a cash-and-stock deal worth at least $159 million.

headline: Consumer Credit Expands
summary: Consumer borrowing unexpectedly rose in April largely due to loans for cars, vacations and other things, but it fell substantially in March.

headline: Apple May Jump-Start Mobile Ads
summary: Steve Jobs said that Apple's iAd platform, its mobile advertising network, will go live on July 1, introducing yet another disruptive force in the media industry.

headline: Former Massey Miner Files Whistleblower Complaint
summary: A former Massey miner alleged that he was fired after he made comments about conditions at two of the company's mines, including one where 29 miners were killed in April.

summary: Options traders appeared to be preparing for Walgreen shares to rebound and for CVS Caremark shares to struggle after Walgreen said it was pulling out of CVS's drug-benefits network.

headline: Rig Blast Widows Back Offshore Drilling
summary: The widows of two Deepwater Horizon crew members voiced their support for continuing to drill offshore at a congressional hearing even as they said they want more safety enforcement.

summary: Tenet said it was unable to "convey to shareholders the potential value, including the inherent risks and opportunities" of the transaction.

summary: Losing blood can be painful. But selling it can produce excellent returns—as the Cerberus deal to part with Talecris shows.

headline: The Euro Will Survive
summary: The costs of returning to 16 separate currencies outweigh the difficulties of keeping the monetary union together.

headline: Columnist Charen Wins Eric Breindel Award
summary: Mona Charen won the Eric Breindel Award for Excellence in Journalism, an annual prize named after a former New York Post columnist and editorial-page editor.

headline: Seven Hurt in W.Va. Gas Well Blast
summary: A crew drilling a natural gas well through an abandoned coal mine in West Virginia's Northern Panhandle hit a pocket of methane gas that ignited, triggering an explosion that burned seven workers.

headline: New York Photos of the Week: May 29 - June 4
summary: Air show pilot Sean D. Tucker, the opening of Luna Park at Coney Island and a swarm of bees on Wall Street.

headline: Oil Steadies; Saudis See Oil at $70-$80 as 'Fair'
summary: Crude futures traded close to unchanged, as the oil market struggled to shake off a gloomy economic outlook that drove prices sharply lower at the end of last week.

headline: European Markets' Losses Mount
summary: European stocks fell sharply, extending losses late in the session as U.S. stocks retreated.

headline: Recession Brings Tough Love to Family Firms
summary: In the current economy, some family businesses are turning down job requests from relatives. Others are slashing salaries for hired kin.

headline: Nordea Ethical Funds Exit BP
summary: Nordea said its ethical funds sold off all investments in BP following the company's handling of the oil spill in the U.S. Gulf of Mexico.

summary: BP says its spent about $1.25 billion to try and cap oil spewing from the sea floor of the Gulf of Mexico, and its containment cap is catching some oil. Still, animals are dying.

headline: Two Firms Seek Hong Kong IPOs
summary: A Chinese pipe maker and a technology company started road shows to raise a total of over half a billion dollars from Hong Kong investors, demonstrating the promise some still see in the market for initial public offerings there despite volatility.

headline: Mongolia to List Major Asset
summary: Mongolian Prime Minister Sukhbaatar Batbold plans to list 20% to 30% of Tavan Tolgoi, the country's giant coking coal deposit, on the Mongolian Stock Exchange

headline: AstraZeneca Drug Works In Thyroid Cancer
summary: Results of a study involving an experimental drug showed it extends the time before a type of rare thyroid cancer gets worse.

headline: Grifols to Acquire Talecris
summary: Grifols said it has agreed to buy Talecris, a U.S. maker of plasma medicines part-owned by Cerberus, for $3.4 billion.

headline: Japanese Yields Slide
summary: Japanese government bond yields dropped as sliding Asian stock markets sent investors crowding into safe-haven assets.

headline: Hyundai Hit by Strike in India
summary: The Indian unit of Hyundai Motor Co. incurred a loss of $13.9 million due to a production halt at its south India factory following a protest by 150 workers demanding the reinstatement of employees sacked last December.

headline: Citic Hits Bump on Road to Top
summary: Citic Securities Co. has ambitions to be the Goldman Sachs of China. But its latest effort to win new business has hit a hitch, underscoring the pitfalls of China's young financial system as it continues to mature.

headline: Struggle for Justice
summary: A district court in Bhopal convicted eight former officials of Union Carbide India for negligence in connection with the 1984 gas tragedy. The verdict comes more than 25 years after the gas leak.

headline: Euribor Nears Six-Month High
summary: The cost of borrowing three-month euros in the interbank market rose to a near six-month high, as Hungary's woes made euro-zone banks more reluctant to lend to each other.

headline: Ariad Treatment for Leukemia Shows Success
summary: Ariad unveiled updated trial data that show its treatment for patients with drug-resistant leukemia.

headline: German Industrial Orders Rise
summary: German manufacturing orders unexpectedly rose 2.8% in April compared with the previous month, as demand grew at home and abroad, government data showed.

headline: Entergy Shuffles Executives
summary: Power company Entergy unveiled a restructuring plan in an effort to strengthen its regulatory team in the Northeast and consolidate some functions of its nonnuclear wholesale commodity business.

headline: Vivus's ED Treatment Study Results Positive
summary: Vivus announced positive results from a late-stage study of its drug avanafil, designed to treat erectile dysfunction.

headline: Taiwan Exports Surged 58% in May
summary: Taiwan's exports in May surged a faster-than-expected 57.9% from a year earlier to a record monthly high, lending support to the island's economy though inflation remained subdued, giving the central bank room to maintain the loose monetary policy that's helped spur a recovery from last year's slump.

headline: U.K. Premier Warns of Slower Growth
summary: U.K. Prime Minister Cameron signaled reductions in government economic-growth forecasts, and indicated cuts in welfare and public-sector pay.

headline: Renault Makes Joint Bid for Ssangyong
summary: Renault said it has submitted a letter of intent to acquire South Korean auto maker Ssangyong in a project with Nissan and a South Korean subsidiary.

headline: IATA Sees Airline Profits in '10
summary: The world's airlines are recovering at a faster rate than previously expected due to a speedy rebound in passenger numbers and cargo trade.

headline: Nadal Wins Fifth French Open Title
summary: Spain's Rafael Nadal beats Sweden's Robin Soderling in straight sets for fifth Roland Garros title in six years.

headline: Nikkei Has Biggest Fall of Year
summary: Asian stock markets were sharply lower Monday after Wall Street's tumble on concerns over Europe and U.S. jobs data hit risk appetite. The Nikkei fell 3.8%, and the euro hit multi-year lows.

headline: Europe Faces a Glut of Oil Refineries
summary: A glut in global refining capacity is squeezing refiners' profits, particularly in Europe. But companies are reluctant to shut plants because of environmental costs and opposition from governments and unions.

headline: VW Ends Preliminary Talks With Proton
summary: Proton, the Malaysian state-owned car maker, said that a potential tie-up with VW, couldn't be pursued as the German car maker has other priorities.

headline: Grifols to Buy Talecris
summary: Grifols of Spain plans to buy Talecris Biotherapeutics, a U.S. maker of plasma medicines, for more than $3 billion.

headline: China to Review Agricultural Bank IPO
summary: Agricultural Bank of China's $30 billion initial public offering is imminent after China's securities regulator said it would hold a review.

headline: Francoeur's Home Run Lifts Mets
summary: Jeff Francoeur's three-run homer in the seventh inning did more than just complete a five-run comeback in the Mets 7-6 win over the Marlins on Sunday. It also confirmed his own comeback.

headline: Two Avenues to Get Makeovers
summary: The city plans to remake large portions of First and Second avenues by October, adding protected bike lanes and a new bus line that officials say will speed travel times along the corridor.

headline: Lone Star in Talks to Sell KEB Stake
summary: Private-equity firm MBK Partners LP has been in talks to potentially bid for Lone Star Funds' 51% stake in Korea Exchange Bank currently valued at about $3.63 billion, a familiar with the situation said Friday.

headline: 2008: Yang on Leading Yahoo
summary: Yahoo's Jerry Yang, co-founder and chief executive, spoke about why he and president Susan Decker were the right leaders to take the company forward.

headline: Markets Prepare for Week of Turmoil
summary: Markets are bracing for another rocky week as finance ministers around the world ready new defenses to keep the sovereign-debt crisis from spreading.

headline: Resignation Signals Bleak Times for OTB
summary: The chairman of New York City Off-Track Better resigns; Mariano Rivera comes in, goes back out then comes in again; and Brooklyn's Yuri Foreman loses his first fight.

headline: Angels Are Looking to Stock Up in Draft
summary: The Los Angeles Angels are poised to stock up at the MLB Draft. Gripes about the new World Cup ball are likely to die down once the tournament starts. And John Wooden offered up some parting words in a March interview.

headline: Drag on Recovery: Consumers' Debt Cuts
summary: The economic rebound will continue to be fitful as long as consumers continue shedding debt, which looks likely to go on for some time.

headline: New Jersey Test for Tea Party
summary: New Jersey's primary elections Tuesday will test whether conservative tea-party activists can sway congressional races in a traditionally moderate state.

headline: Spend or Cut, Lawmakers Divide
summary: Few in Washington argue the U.S. budget deficit will cure itself, but there's no agreement on what to do about it.

headline: EU Works Out Loan Details
summary: Euro-zone finance ministers meeting in Luxembourg are on track to sign off on the final details of €440 billion in loans intended to be a backstop if Europe's sovereign-debt troubles deepen.

headline: 2007: How Tech Changes Art
summary: Long before "Avatar," filmmaker George Lucas fused film and technology by pushing digital. At the D: conference in 2007, he said any kind of art form is "essentially technological."

headline: Richard Florida: Homeownership Is Overrated
summary: Today's economy requires a more mobile workforce.

headline: Clarification
summary: In a June 2 editorial, the Denver Post said it had asked Colorado Democrat Andrew Romanoff in September if he'd been offered a job by the White House to drop out of the Senate primary and that Mr. Romanoff had "unequivocally" denied he'd been offered a position. Kim Strassel's June 4 Potomac Watch column cited this exchange. In a blog post on June 3, the Denver Post editorial board clarified that its question to Mr. Romanoff came more than a week before Mr. Romanoff had been contacted by the White House.

headline: Austerity At Different Speeds
summary: The timing and depth of Europe's cutbacks vary greatly, and countries that aren't yet under pressure from bond markets are trying to steer a middle way between growth and fiscal rebalancing.

headline: Malaysia v. Israel
summary: The political consensus in Kuala Lumpur is cause for worry.

headline: The Connected Car
summary: On Alan Mulally's watch, Ford models smoothly handle music players and phones. The CEO talked about auto makers at last entering the digital age.

headline: Xinjiang Goldwind Seeks to Expand
summary: Chinese wind-turbine maker Xinjiang Goldwind Science & Technology is seeking to expand overseas to tap raising demand for renewable energy and to boost its profitability.

headline: We'll Beat Them Silly at GDH, Too
summary: Brian Domitrovic  certainly is correct that the effort by European politicians to replace gross domestic product with "gross domestic happiness" (GDH) is a transparent attempt to hide the adverse economic effects of their own policies ("Europe's GDP Envy," op-ed, June 1).

summary: Thousands of soccer fans stampeded outside a stadium in South Africa Sunday before an exhibition game between Nigeria and North Korea, leaving 15 people injured. The mayhem happened only five days before the start of the World Cup.

summary: The credit-raters say 'too big to fail' is alive and well.

summary: By missing a sixth quarterly dividend payment due to the U.S. in May, a Southern California bank is poised to test just how far the government will extend its reach into the smaller corners of the private sector.

summary: Hon Hai's planned pay increase could more than double the minimum wage for some of its workers, marking the Chinese electronics manufacturer's latest effort to improve conditions after a series of employee suicides.

summary: This adviser says investors can cover most of the bases with just six funds.

headline: O'Grady: Chavismo Meets the Market
summary: Venezuela's socialist economic policies are spreading shortages and chaos.

headline: Smash-and-Grab Suspects Nabbed

summary: The petroleum industry is bracing for tougher times now that the Obama administration has put a six-month moratorium on deepwater oil exploration in the wake of the Gulf disaster.

headline: Gerald Steinberg: The New War Against Israel
summary: Terror, lies and slander are the main tools of the Leftist-Islamist alliance against the Jewish state.

summary: Doubts over statements from the IRS have jolted the $2.8 trillion municipal-bond market, raising concern that some states or cities could lose federal interest-rate subsidies on more than $100 billion worth of Build America Bonds.

summary: Among a sea of look-alike funds, some stand out for their unusual approaches. Of course, there may be a reason why many of them don't catch on.

headline: Lee Sharpens Rhetoric at Pyongyang
summary: South Korean President Lee Myung-bak over the weekend sharpened his criticism of North Korea for the alleged sinking of one the South's warships, but acknowledged his country can't go to war over it.

headline: The IPO Facade: Big Names Mask Slump
summary: A string of big-name companies that have filed to go public in recent weeks has obscured a less-encouraging trend: The pace of new companies registering for IPOs fell in May and more deals were shelved than at any point this year.

headline: Partner's Many Gaffes Hurt Merkel's Reach
summary: Missteps by the junior coalition partner to Merkel's Christian Democratic Union could make it less likely that Germany will be able to push through economic overhauls.

headline: Official: Euro's Fall Isn't a Big Concern
summary: Euro-zone Chairman Juncker said the current level of the euro isn't a concern, but called for improved government across the euro area and greater cooperation between countries using the currency.

headline: College Pitchers Offer Better Value
summary: Since 2000, more MLB All-Star pitchers have been drafted from college than high school, but the average bonus for a high-school pitcher since 2007 is $2.41 million compared with $2.03 million for a college ace.

headline: Crovitz: Even Technologists Can't Predict the Future
summary: Steve Jobs says the era of personal computers may be ending. Steve Ballmer disagrees.

headline: All Things Digital
summary: At the eighth D conference, the theme was change. A selection of edited interview excerpts shows a fundamental shift in how we all relate to computing.

summary: The world's leading economic powers edged toward agreement on new rules to ensure that major banks keep enough money in reserve to insulate them against future crises.

headline: Train Buffs Try to Save Railroad to Nowhere
summary: A group of passionate volunteers in Argentina is clearing the track of the defunct General Manuel Belgrano Railroad, in hopes the train will run again.

summary: When American Craig Naylor assumes the helm of Nippon Sheet Glass, he'll become one of a handful of foreign chiefs of Japanese firms.

summary: …Here are five key questions to ask. Sure, it's easy to select an all-in-one fund geared to a year you might retire in. But what exactly are you getting?

summary: New York's ailing construction industry is getting a lift from the City University of New York as it pursues its 10-year plan to become a world leader in science research and teacher training.

summary: FCC Chairman Julius Genachowski talked about increasing broadband speeds, unleashing mobile broadband and unlocking innovation in cable set-top boxes.

summary: Oscar-winning director James Cameron has pushed the boundaries of technology in making films. He talked about a 3-D "Titanic," cleaning up the Gulf oil spill and watching movies on a phone.

summary: In "Delivering Happiness," Tony Hsieh traces his path to success so far—at the website network LinkExchange and, more momentously, at Zappos.com, the Internet shoe retailer. Paul Carroll reviews.

summary: Multinational liquor companies such as Pernod Ricard and Diageo are investing in production facilities in Scotland at a level not seen in the whisky business since the 1970s.

summary: NPR chief Vivian Schiller came talked about the rise of Internet radio, getting programs on the iPad and how public radio can thrive in the digital age.

headline: Foundation to Spread Love of Cuban Art, Culture
summary: A retired real-estate investor and art collector will create a foundation to spread his love for Cuban art and culture.

headline: U.S., China Show Military Wariness
summary: The wary relationship between the militaries of the U.S. and China flared openly—though courteously—at a conference this weekend, a brief flash of the long-standing tension that's centered on Taiwan but extends to their broader alliances and differing worldviews.

headline: Two N.J. Men Charged in Terror Probe
summary: Two New Jersey men were arrested as they tried to board flights to Egypt to join a terror group, prosecutors said.

headline: Internet Week Helps Sector Connect
summary: Keynote speakers for Internet Week New York include Arianna Huffington and Martha Stewart. Pete Wentz of the band Fall Out Boy and Kraft executive Howard Friedman will share a panel.

headline: The Leaky Border Is Nothing New
summary: Regarding Edward Alden's "The Meaningless Mantra of 'Border Security' " (op-ed, June 2): As a young Second Lt., I was stationed at Luke Air Force Base in Arizona from 1968 to 1970 as an aircraft controller in the SAGE air defense system. Our primary mission was to control fighter air and protect U.S. airspace.

headline: BP Aims to Repair Image With Ads
summary: BP is pressing ahead with an elaborate advertising campaign it hopes will rescue its badly damaged image.

headline: Author Finds Inspiration in Humor
summary: Danielle Ganek's second novel, "The Summer We Read Gatsby," is about two half-sisters looking for love in the Hamptons.

headline: Adviser Alert: Sweeter Deals for Brokers
summary: Two big securities firms have enhanced the recruiting packages they use to attract advisers from competitors.

headline: Former Broker Is Now the Underdog
summary: Former Rep. Pombo, the onetime Washington power broker, is counting on anger over federal water policies in California to propel him back into office in November.

headline: The People's Diva Goes Pop
summary: Opera star Renée Fleming makes a foray into rock with "Dark Hope," an album comprised of covers of Death Cab for Cutie, Peter Gabriel and other pop acts.

headline: College Accreditation Groups Scrutinized
summary: Groups that accredit colleges and universities are facing new scrutiny after the Education Department's inspector general urged officials to curtail the authority of the nation's largest regional oversight group.

headline: Texas Big-Screen Uproar
summary: Texans are bombarding the governor's office with calls and letters to try to stop tax dollars from subsidizing a satirical film about a vengeful illegal immigrant.

headline: Bank Valuations Just Can't Keep Up
summary: While bank earnings have bounced back from the worst days of the crisis, valuations haven't followed suit, and it may be some time before they do.

headline: The Stars Shine for Shakespeare
summary: Wednesday marks the start of the Public Theater's Shakespeare in the Park season. With two plays—"Merchant of Venice" and "The Winter's Tale"—in repertory until August 1, New Yorkers have some choices to make: One or both? If only one, then which?

headline: Giving Government Incentives to Save
summary: The White House plans to ask Congress for new authority that could help to discourage unnecessary spending by federal agencies, a move meant to show the administration is serious about tackling the government's budget deficit.

headline: Funds of Their Very Own
summary: After  years as investors, some advisers take a stab at portfolio management.

headline: AT&T Wireless Plan May Lift Cable
summary: AT&T's decision to shift its wireless-data pricing to a usage-based model is music to the ears of cable executives because it could expand use of wireline-broadband connections at home, an area dominated by cable operators.

headline: The Weak-Euro Myth
summary: Devaluation is a recipe for a weak currency and an unreformed economy saddled with crushing levels of debt.

headline: Park East Synagogue Marks Milestones
summary: The synagogue will celebrate its 120th anniversary and also honor Rabbi Arthur Schneier, who is celebrating his 80th birthday and his 48th year at the Park East.

headline: Crisis Panel Accuses Goldman of Stalling
summary: A government commission probing the financial crisis denounced Goldman Sachs, saying the firm dragged its feet over requests for information and dumped hundreds of millions of documents on the panel.

headline: Euro to Remain Under Pressure
summary: Hungary's debt problem has added another worry that will weigh on the euro. The common currency has fallen below $1.20, leaving it within sight of the $1.18 level at which it exited its first day of trading in 1999.

headline: Japanese Premier Affirms U.S. Ties
summary: Japan's new prime minister made his diplomatic debut in a telephone call with President Obama, reaffirming his country's alliance with Washington and promising to work hard on an agreement to relocate a contentious U.S. Marine base.

headline: Arkansas Race Tests Union Pull
summary: Labor leaders have repeatedly warned incumbent Democrats not to take their endorsements for granted. In a runoff election in Arkansas, unions will get a chance to prove they mean it.

headline: Rafael Nadal's Win: What Sports Needed
summary: After a tumultuous week for sports, it was comforting to see a neon-colored Rafael Nadal flopping around in the red French clay.

headline: No Magic Bullet in the Yuan-Dollar Relationship
summary: Prof. Ray C. Fair ("The Yin and Yang of Yuan Appreciation," June 1) explains how four links between the U.S. and China would offset each other to negate any gain to the U.S. from a yuan revaluation. In particular, he stresses that prices of imports would rise leading to a decline in real wealth and a fall in real wages, "since nominal wages adjust slowly to increasing prices."

headline: New iPhone Faces High Hopes
summary: Expectations are high for the unveiling of the new iPhone this week at Apple's Worldwide Developers Conference, though many details are widely known.

headline: Notable & Quotable
summary: Victor Davis Hanson on the flotilla and Turkey's glass house.
